captions.text: [CAR ENGINE]

MATT FARAH: If you've seen many
episodes of Tuned, you'll

know that the kind of shops
we visit put a really big
emphasis on horsepower--

everything is 700, 800, 900,
1,000, 1,200 horsepower.
It really never seems to end.

But today we're at Monticello
Motor Club, which is one of my

favorite places to drive
a sports car.

And Turner Motorsport, who is
based out of Massachusetts,

has graciously brought
us two vehicles.

On my right, we have a Frozen
Gray M3 street car that's been

modified by Turner
to their liking.

In fact, it's Will Turner's
personal car.

And on my left, we have the
2011 Continental Series GS

Class Championship-winning
car, the number 96 Turner
Motorsports M3.

And today, I am fortunate enough
to get to drive both.

And we're going to find out why,
while other companies put

an emphasis on horsepower,
Turner's
priorities go like this--

breaking, grip, handling,
and then horsepower.

Sometimes horsepower
isn't everything.

And for a company that spends
most of its time on the

racetrack as opposed to the
street, it's starting to make
a lot of sense.

I'm Matt Farah, and you're
watching Tuned.

I'm pretty excited right now
because while we drive a lot

of huge horsepower cars, we do
not drive cars by people who
are really about going racing.
And that's what Turner does.
They build
championship-winning race cars.

And so they really haven't
focused too much on giant
power with this car.
It's more about the dynamics.

Well, I'll start
with the power.
Its stroked.

527 horsepower, normally
aspirated engine.

It's stroked to 4.6 liters,
which is very nice, with an

Akrapovic full exhaust,
high flow cast.

But that's really it for
the power department.

Huge StopTech brakes right out
of their Grand-Am car.

Six piston front, four
piston rear.

Big 14 inch discs,
drilled discs.

And then in the suspension
tuning, we've got the brand
new KW DDC suspension.

And what DDC stands for is
dynamic damper control.

So when you see some really
top end cars where you can

adjust comfort or sport, usually
you can't do that with
an after-market suspension.

You have to get under the
car, turn some knobs,
maybe turn a wrench.
Not so here.

You've got a button
right here.
And it's on comfort right now.
I'll go to full sport.
Three settings--

comfort, sport, and
sport plus.

You can connect with your iPhone
or your iPad and adjust
it via the KW app.

Which is super cool because
while the button just has

three modes-- comfort, sport,
and support plus--

the app, you can actually adjust
front and rear bias.

You can adjust sides
independently from each other.
You can make preset settings.

You've got to give props to this
transmission because it
shifts really fast.

You know, the AMG cars, they
have that wet clutch.
And it works.

I mean, you shift with the
paddles and it works.

But it doesn't give you the
race car feel the same way
this transmission does.
It shifts so fast.

Just pop, boom, boom, boom,
fires off shifts so fast.
There's 120.
Passing 130.
There's 140.
And I'm out of juice.

Oh, these brakes really bring
you down nice, don't they?

Big break upgrade, so key
if you're going to
be doing track time.

These are basically full
on race brakes.

There's a little bit of
understeer coming through the

tight corners, but that's how
it goes with street cars.
I like this car a lot.

There's no turbo lag, no
supercharger heat buildup,

just all-motor, 527
horsepower, 407
pound-feet of torque.

That's about 113 horsepower
more than a stock M3.

I'll be honest, I do not know
what this car does,
acceleration numbers.

But it feels significantly
more muscular
than a regular M3.
It sounds more muscular.

It feels like it was done by
somebody who goes racing, not

by a dino tuner, a tuner that
just wants big power for the
sake of big power.

Now don't get me wrong,
there is nothing
wrong with big power.

I personally am a huge
fan of big power.

But when you're on the track,
something about balance,
something about the harmony.
It's all in harmony.

Everything this car's doing
is totally predictable and
progressive.

For those of you asking me
to drift, hey, go [BLEEP]
yourself.
I'm in an open track session.

Just judging on how good this
car is, it makes me very

excited to drive
their race car.
They do a lot of racing.
They're racing every weekend.

And I get to drive Bill
Auberlin's race car.

Very famous BMW factory
driver.

He's been driving with Turner
for many years.

And he is one of, if not the
best BMW driver out there.

Maybe Joey Hand, but Joey Hand
used to drive for Turner.

These guys are employed every
top, top notch BMW
driver there is.

And today, I get to
drive their car.
How [BLEEP]
cool is that?
[TECHNO MUSIC]

KEVIN HOLMES: Here you're going
to see on the dash,
pretty standard, attack--

MATT FARAH: Attack,
speedometer?
KEVIN HOLMES: Nope.

MATT FARAH: Oh, no
that's just--
KEVIN HOLMES: Gear position.
MATT FARAH: Oh.
KEVIN HOLMES: OK.
It'll only do it when--

MATT FARAH: When the
engine's on, OK.

KEVIN HOLMES: No, when you're
actually rolling.

It needs the engine on
and wheels rolling
to calculate it.
It's a conversion.

Not conversion, it's
not actually at
different gear positions.
MATT FARAH: OK.

KEVIN HOLMES: There's a lot
more information here.

MATT FARAH: Do I
need any of it?
KEVIN HOLMES: Nope.
MATT FARAH: OK.
KEVIN HOLMES: No.
MATT FARAH: Good to know.

KEVIN HOLMES: It's gear diff
temp, gearbox temp, fuel

pressure, oil pressure,
oil temp.

MATT FARAH: I can't believe
people scroll through all this
crap while driving.

That to me is like-- like,
I talk while driving.

And that is hard for
a lot of people.

KEVIN HOLMES: Yeah, I mean Bill
Auberlin will actually

change pages because we have
three pages in here.

This is the race
page, practice.

And he'll go over, and he'll
be watching the lambdas.

Pretty much for a race, we're
on the race page.

Engine temp, fuel remaining,
ground speed, gear position,

attack-- those are the only
things that we're really--
MATT FARAH: OK.

And this is shift
lights up here?
KEVIN HOLMES: Yup.

So they'll come in from the
outer to the center.

And they'll get progressive, and
they'll start flashing red
when it's time to shift.
And that's when you can shift.
MATT FARAH: OK.

And what's all this
other crap?

So cool suit, which I'm
not using right now.

But cool suit's the
best thing ever.
It's great.
KEVIN HOLMES: Pretty much.
And then you've got--
MATT FARAH: This is--
KEVIN HOLMES: --ABS maps.

And then you've got the helmet
blower on your right, which

that we'll plug in for
you because it works
awesome in this car.

MATT FARAH: What's the clutch
like on this thing?
The pedal feels OK.
KEVIN HOLMES: Yeah.

It's OS Giken double
disc clutch, works
pretty much like standard.
MATT FARAH: OK.
You have an awesome mirror.
KEVIN HOLMES: Yup.
Mirror's really good.

We'll adjust the outer mirrors
once you get happy.

MATT FARAH: And this is brake
bias, which I'm not using.
KEVIN HOLMES: Correct.

MATT FARAH: What's
it set to now?
Standard?
KEVIN HOLMES: Well--
MATT FARAH: Whatever.
KEVIN HOLMES: No.
MATT FARAH: No?
[LAUGHING]

KEVIN HOLMES: No, that's
something we work a lot.
But it's all set up right now.
It's good to go.
MATT FARAH: OK.
And I'm on map number three.
Is that what I want?
KEVIN HOLMES: Yup.
That's our full power map.

MATT FARAH: Full power
map, all right.
Good.

So I'm pretty much not going
to mess with it.

I'm just going to start it and
then just go drive it.
KEVIN HOLMES: Yes.
Absolutely.
MATT FARAH: All right.
I can do this.
Sure.
Go.
[CAR ENGINE]
MATT FARAH: All right.

My first time in a real
professional race car.

I've got slick tires, try to
heat them up a little bit.

I'm going to take it
easy because--
I'll be honest--
I'm nervous as hell.
OK.
Tires are a little slick.

Brakes are way different
from the street car.
Interesting pedal pressure.

This is the coolest goddamn
thing I've ever gotten to do.

All right, the throttle by wire
requires a lot less pedal
pressure than I thought.

A heel toe down shift,
that's OK.

Shifter feel-- oh, it does not
like to be on and off the gas.
OK.

You got to kind of give
it the old boot.
OK.

I'm pretty sure there's
heat in the tires now.
I have no traction control.

But according to Will, I have
a really badass ABS system.
Wow, those brakes.

Once you get some heat in
them, those are some
ridiculous brakes.
This car weighs 3,310 pounds.

With a full tank of fuel It's
actually barely lighter than
the street car.

I'm trying to think of
statistics right now, but all

I'm thinking is, go faster
and don't die.

It's just over 400 horsepower,
but you'd never know it.
It feels fast as [BLEEP].

Looking out of the car, it feels
like the in-car view

from all those races I've
always watched.
Wow.

This is why race cars are so
much better than street cars.
I finally feel like I get it.
And you know what?
I'm glad it's stick.

In the street car, I'm a
big fan of the pedals.
[CAR ENGINE]
MATT FARAH: Woohoo!
Yeah!
These brakes are unbelievable.
I love it.
I love it.

The throttle's a little bit
like an on-off switch.

But that's OK because once the
tires get heat in them, you

can just go through
corners so fast.
[CAR ENGINE]

MATT FARAH: Oh, this is the
greatest day of my life.

Oh, fast street cars
are one thing.

Professional race driver, that
is the best job in the world.
Oh yeah, buddy.

Other than just simple getting
used to and stuff it's really
not very difficult to drive.

I mean it honestly just
feels like the best
M3 I've ever driven.

I will never be a racing driver,
but it's so great to
pretend even just for one day.
Hell mother [BLEEP]
yeah, buddy!
[CAR ENGINE]
MATT FARAH: Woo!

This car started out as a bone
stock M3 right off the
production line.
And now listen to it.

The slicks are really,
really sticky now.

Obviously they're Continentals
because this is a Continental
Series car.
[CAR ENGINE]

MATT FARAH: So how
about it then?

Flat out, down the
front straight.
[CAR ENGINE]
MATT FARAH: Oh, I'm psyched.

It is not nearly as forgiving
as a street car, and it's

properly intimidating
to drive.
But goddamn is it fun.

It's not that it has melt
your face horsepower.
It doesn't.

In fact, it's really not all
that fast in a straight line.

But the sound, the directness of
everything, the way your--

my senses are going
crazy in this car.
[CAR ENGINE]

MATT FARAH: Driving a
real race car is--

it's like the automotive
equivalent of
doing ecstasy or something.

All your synapses are just
firing like crazy.
Adrenaline's going.

You just never want the
session to end.
Oh, it's so unbelievably good.

I'm sorry I'm sweating
up your helmet, Will.

But I just don't want to get
off the track right now.

They're going to have to drag
me out of this car.
[CAR ENGINE]

MATT FARAH: And there's
the checker.
That's my last lap.

I'm going to cool
her down now.
Oh, man.

That was just about the best
thing I've ever done.
It's crazy.
It's really crazy.

Once you aren't scared of the
car anymore, it's so fun.

Now I know why people get
addicted to this stuff.

Tried to talk, think
I even might have
succeeded in some talking.
But it's crazy.
Crazy good.

So much better than any
street car, man.

It's not even like crazy fast
in a straight line.

But huck it through a corner,
and it [BLEEP]
sticks.
It's in one piece.
Success.

I need to go apologize
to somebody for
staying out too long.

As we conclude our second
season of Tuned--

a season full of street cars
over stuffed with horsepower--

there's a lesson to be learned
from these two Turner M3s, a

lesson that can only be learned
by driving cars built

by people who spend most
of their time racing.

When building a fast street car,
lots of horsepower is a
good thing.

But not as good as
creating balance.

With Turner's Frozen Gray M3,
everything feels upgraded to
an equal degree.

The engine, chassis, suspension,
brakes, and tires

are all in harmony with each
other, elevating the

performance of the M3 in all
areas, whether you're driving
on the street or on the track.

No aspect of the car feels like
it's overshadowing the

driving experience or creating
an instability.

It's the same feeling I get
from driving the race car.

Though the experience of
borrowing a $250,000 race

machine three days before
it needs to run is an

intimidating as experience
as I've ever had.

The car itself feels
wonderful.

Once you trust the slick
tires, it's not scary.
It's just fun.

You feel everything through
the controls.

You hear everything through
the uninsulated body.

And every aspect of the
car is under your
control at all times.

Horsepower is a wonderful
thing.

We've certainly experienced
plenty of it this season.

But while horsepower is fun to
use in short bursts, nothing

puts a smile on your face every
time you drive it like a
perfectly balanced sports car.

With these two machines,
Turner Motorsport
has achieved that.
And I have to say, I like it.

I missed the checker and
took an extra lap.
I'm sorry.
KEVIN HOLMES: No, no, no.
Come here.
MATT FARAH: My bad.

It was my first time in
a proper race car.

KEVIN HOLMES: Consider
your wrist slapped.

MATT FARAH: I got
very excited.

KEVIN HOLMES: You got a
little carried away?

MATT FARAH: Well, trying to
drive and talk, and there's a
camera in front of my face.
I'm sorry.
KEVIN HOLMES: That's OK.
MATT FARAH: My bad.
KEVIN HOLMES: Yeah.
Don't do it again.

MATT FARAH: That was the
greatest thing ever.

KEVIN HOLMES: That car's
pretty insane.

MATT FARAH: Real race
cars are awesome.

KEVIN HOLMES: Not just a real
race car, a champion.

MATT FARAH: Like a proper
real race car.

KEVIN HOLMES: A proper
winning race car.
MATT FARAH: I didn't stall it.
I didn't crash it.
KEVIN HOLMES: All positives.

MATT FARAH: It's the
best thing ever.

KEVIN HOLMES: So when
are we going to
catch you in the Series?

title: Turner Motorsport's 535 hp Frozen Gray BMW M3 and Championship-Winning M3 Race Car - /TUNED
